<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 325, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025

1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 917, 104]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 410, 135]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 625, 441]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 440, 918, 471]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 484, 918, 516]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 682, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 457, 121]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 610, 152]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 572, 183]]<|/det|>
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 196, 915, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 518, 533, 535]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 551, 148, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 551, 180, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 551, 752, 568]]<|/det|>
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 581, 912, 600]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 613, 183, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 613, 915, 645]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** technique used to ensure that the room temperature reading is as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 688, 915, 705]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|> The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 801, 136]]<|/det|> He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 555, 167]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure for beaker B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 181, 737, 197]]<|/det|> It is important that the temperatures are recorded at exactly every 30s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 747, 228]]<|/det|> Describe a technique which will make it easier for the student to do that. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 368, 725, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 335, 539, 351]]<|/det|> Table 2.1
beaker A with insulationbeaker B without insulation
t/sθ/°Cθ/°C
092.593.0
3090.590.5
6089.088.5
9087.587.0
12086.085.5
15085.084.0
18085.583.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 146, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 610, 917, 642]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 747, 918, 765]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 183, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 917, 104]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 116, 555, 147]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{T},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 157, 917, 190]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 205, 328, 221]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 265, 917, 282]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \text{................................................................................} [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 297, 180, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 297, 917, 330]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 341, 564, 373]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{T},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 383, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 430, 328, 446]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 490, 917, 510]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \text{................................................................................} [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 146, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 917, 553]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t = 0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 784, 585]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 660, 917, 679]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 120, 640, 136]]<|/det|>

<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 243, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 338, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 500, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 917, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 142, 550, 170]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 180, 833, 197]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 211, 405, 228]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 318, 258]]<|/det|>
· a selection of wires

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 260, 354, 274]]<|/det|>
· a variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 276, 260, 289]]<|/det|>
· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 256, 305]]<|/det|>
· a voltmeter.

In your plan:
